posts.name: Jared Van Horn
posts.cooked: Our team has the adafruit 5mm beam break sensors and I was unsure of how to wire them. Do we need to power them via vrm or can they be powered through pwm from the roborio?

posts.name: Parker Harris
posts.cooked: They can be powered through the pwm on the roborio, just make sure that all the wires go to the correct pin on the rio

posts.name: Ken Pontbriant
posts.cooked: The Adafruit beam break sensors can plug directly into roborio digital I/O. The I/O pins can deliver more than enough current to run a transmit/receive pair. We are doing exactly the same thing with them.

posts.name: James
posts.cooked: I agree with the above post. We also use DIO to power and get the sensor state. If you need code here is an example 2024-Crescendo/2024 Crescendo/src/main/java/frc/robot/subsystems/IntakeSubsystem.java at main · FRC3546/2024-Crescendo · GitHub

posts.name: Carlos Valenzuela
posts.cooked: We use the 5mm adafruit ones as well and yes, you need to wire them to the vrm if you want the complete range of the sensor as we encountered that the voltage that the rio provides isn’t enough to get the complete range.

posts.name: Kabir
posts.cooked: Hi! We are using the beam break sensors for the first time and I was wondering if it would be possible to get a photo of the beam break wired to the Roborio? If that is not possible, that’s alright!

posts.name: Domtech
posts.cooked:
Basically just wire it like the hall effect sensor example on this page:

A digital signal is a signal that can be in one of several discrete states. In the vast majority of cases, the signal is the voltage in a wire, and there are only two states for a digital signal - ...

If you are using SparkMAX and want to run it to your motor controller you can wire it as a limit switch to one of the breakout boards. Red to 5V, black to ground, white yellow to limit, and a 10kohm resistor between red and white yellow :

CarlosA:

you need to wire them to the vrm if you want the complete range of the sensor as we encountered that the voltage that the rio provides isn’t enough to get the complete range.

That should not be true, the Rio DIO pins provide 5V.

posts.name: Ken Pontbriant
posts.cooked:
I’m nowhere near the robot but I’ll give this a try.

First, the sensor wires need the female Molex contacts that will plug into the Rio I/O pins.

The Rio digital I/O pins go signal, power, ground from inside to outside. The sensor with 3 wires (the receiver) connects yellow to signal, red to power, black to ground. This I/O channel is what you will read in code.

Now you need to power the 2-wire sensor (the transmitter). You can use another I/O channel for that, with red to power and black to ground. You don’t need to do anything in code for that channel.

posts.name: Kabir
posts.cooked:
Thank you so much! Just a clarifying question, and I attached an image, but both sensors have to be between the pins that I circled, right? I am new to FRC electrical and I am not sure about anything, so thank you for bearing with me! Screenshot 2024-03-15 155936 1326×436 31 KB

posts.name: Domtech
posts.cooked:
Looking at this screenshot from that page: image 910×564 28.2 KB For the DIO (Digital In or Out):

image 910×564 28.2 KB

image 910×564 28.2 KB

All of the left pins are connected to ground (0 volts)

All the center pins are connected to regulated 5V

The right pins are the signal channels numbered 0-9 Each signal pin has a 40Kohm resistor connecting it to 5V

You can power your sensors from any of the ground or 5V pins, they are all connected together inside the RIO.

The signal pins are the ones you access in code, either for input (read) or output (write). Because of the resistor they normally float at 5V, but when acting as an output the RIO can switch them to output either 3.3V (on) or 0V (off).

When acting as an input they read high due to the resistor, until the break beam detects something and grounds that pin to 0V. The exact behavior is described at the bottom bottom of that page: image 838×60 2.94 KB

image 838×60 2.94 KB

image 838×60 2.94 KB

You can use whichever sensor pins you want  you just have to call the corresponding pin number in code

Since it sounds like you are just getting started, here are the basics of the other RoboRIO ports:

The Analog Ports have a very similar arrangement to the DIO pins, however the signal pin is only an input and can read variable voltage between 0 and 5 Volts.

The PWM Ports are also very similar to the DIO, but instead of 5V, they provide 6V so that they can power small servos, and the signal pin is only an output (although much faster to achieve Pulse Width Modulation for motor or LED control)

The Relay ports each have 2 output pins, a “forward” and “reverse” that can be independently switched between 0V (off) and 5V (on).

posts.name: Domtech
posts.cooked:
The plugs should be on the pins not in between them

Edit, ah I see the confusion. The connectors on the beam break have the wrong “gender”. If you have received the KOP this year or recently then you should have some cables like these around that can be used to plug it in:
